Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the mother needs to correct the behavior
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was standing in line at the polling station, my ballot envelope in hand, when my son darted away from my side, weaving between the supermarket aisles that doubled as our voting site. I caught the poll worker’s eye as she noticed the smudge on my envelope. “Ma’am, could you please re-sign this? It’s important for your vote to count,” she said gently, holding out a pen. At the same moment, I heard a crash—my son had knocked over a display of cereal boxes. My heart pounded. I knew I needed to teach him not to run wild in public, to respect rules and other people’s space. But the poll worker was waiting, and I’d always believed in the importance of following voting procedures exactly, setting an example as a responsible citizen. My son’s wide eyes met mine, full of mischief and a hint of fear, while the poll worker’s patient smile was tinged with urgency. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing on me, unsure which expectation to meet first.
